Package me.dessie.dessielib.particleapi.collison

Class ParticleCollider<T>

java.lang.Object
me.dessie.dessielib.particleapi.collison.ParticleCollider<T>
Type Parameters:
T - Any object within the Minecraft world that could be collided with.
Direct Known Subclasses:
BlockCollider, EntityCollider
public abstract class ParticleCollider<T> extends Object
Calls consumers when a ShapedParticle's particle collides with something in the world.
See Also:
  • BlockCollider
  • If creating a custom collider, extend this class and override ParticleCollider#attemptCollide(ShapedParticle, World, List)

  • Constructor Details

    • ParticleCollider

      public ParticleCollider(Consumer<T> collider, int delay)
      Parameters:
      collider - A consumer for what to do when a particle collides with the object.
      delay - How much time, in ticks, to wait between each collision event. For example, if this is 60, the collider will only be called for the same object every 3 seconds.

    • ParticleCollider

      public ParticleCollider(Consumer<T> collider, int delay, boolean multiCollide)
      Parameters:
      collider - A consumer for what to do when a particle collides with the object.
      delay - How much time, in ticks, to wait between each collision event. For example, if this is 60, the collider will only be called for the same object every 3 seconds.
      multiCollide - If multiple particles can collide with the same object per tick. (Meaning multiple calls to the consumer)

  • Method Details

    • getDelay

      public int getDelay()
      Returns:
      The amount of ticks between each call to the collision consumer for the same object.

    • isMultiCollide

      public boolean isMultiCollide()
      Returns:
      If multiple particles can collide with the same object per tick.

    • getCollider

      public Consumer<T> getCollider()
      Returns:
      The consumer that is applied when there is a collision.

    • setCollider

      public ParticleCollider<T> setCollider(Consumer<T> collider)
      Parameters:
      collider - Sets the consumer for what is applied when a particle collides with a block.
      Returns:
      The ParticleCollider instance.

    • setMultiCollide

      public ParticleCollider<T> setMultiCollide(boolean multiCollide)
      Parameters:
      multiCollide - Sets if multiple particles can collide with the same object per tick.
      Returns:
      The ParticleCollider instance.

    • setDelay

      public ParticleCollider<T> setDelay(int delay)
      Parameters:
      delay - Sets the amount of ticks between each call to the collision consumer for the same object.
      Returns:
      The ParticleCollider instance.

    • attemptCollide

      protected abstract void attemptCollide(ShapedParticle particle, org.bukkit.World world, List<org.bukkit.util.Vector> points)
      If you're writing your own Colliders for an object, you'll need to override this method. To call your Consumer, you can use Consumer.accept(Object)
      Parameters:
      particle - The ShapedParticle that was rendered and could collide with something.
      world - The world that the ShapedParticle was rendered in.
      points - A list of particle locations within the rendered ShapedParticle.

    • add

      protected void add(T object)
      Marks an object as collided with. This should always be called when the object has been collidied with in your attemptCollide(ShapedParticle, World, List) The delay and frame collision will be applied to this object, to properly prevent it from being collided with improperly.
      Parameters:
      object - The object to mark as a collided with

    • canCollide

      protected boolean canCollide(T object)
      Returns if a provided object is able to be collided with. An object must not have an active delay, and if MultiCollide is off, it must not have been collided with this frame.
      Parameters:
      object - The object to check collision for.
      Returns:
      If the Object is valid for a collision.

    • doDelayCalculate

      protected void doDelayCalculate(ShapedParticle particle)
      Decrements the delay for the ShapedParticle. This should always been called in your startCollide(ShapedParticle, World, List) method, if overrode. Generally, before any canCollide(Object) calls have been made.
      Parameters:
      particle - The ShapedParticle to calculate for.

    • startCollide

      public void startCollide(ShapedParticle particle, org.bukkit.World world, List<org.bukkit.util.Vector> points)
      Starts a collision for a Particle. This will be called on every animation from of a ShapedParticle.
      Parameters:
      particle - The ShapedParticle to check collisions for
      world - The World to check collisions in
      points - The points on the ShapedParticle to check collisions for.
      See Also:
      • ParticleAnimator
      • To change how often collisions occur.
